Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with reminders about tonight’s family dinner. My stepdad had planned it for weeks, hoping to bring us all closer. As a step-sibling, I knew how much it meant to him—and to my mom—that I show up, smile, and make an effort to bond with my stepbrother, even though we barely spoke outside these gatherings. But just as I was about to get ready, my stepbrother texted me privately, asking if I could cover for him. He wanted to sneak out with friends, planning to drink and party, and he needed me to tell the adults he was feeling sick.

My heart pounded. As a Christian, honesty and integrity are values I try to live by, even when it’s hard. Lying for him felt wrong, but I also knew refusing might make things even more awkward between us, maybe even ruin the fragile peace we’d built. The pressure from both sides squeezed me, and I felt trapped—torn between being the supportive step-sibling everyone expected and staying true to my faith. I sat on my bed, phone in hand, wrestling with what to do next.
